Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Liver Transplantation for Non-Resectable Colorectal Liver Metastases

Trial_Design.evidence: No randomisation or blinding was employed.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included good performance status and absence of extrahepatic disease.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the long-term quality of life (QoL) and overall survival (OS) in patients with non-resectable colorectal liver metastases (CRLM) undergoing liver transplantation (LT).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was OS at 2 years, with secondary outcomes including disease-free survival and QoL.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: No randomisation or blinding was employed.

Blinding.evidence: No randomisation or blinding was employed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: involving 23 patients with non-resectable liver-only CRLM.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Seven patients died within 3 years, with higher baseline symptom scores correlating with lower OS.

Harms.evidence: At 3 months post-LT, patients reported reduced QoL, physical function, and increased dyspnoea.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The study was registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01311453)
